text.p: These are the leading stories in the Egyptian press on Monday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
AL-AHRAM

- In an atmosphere of escalating anger in the occupied territories, Foreign Minister Amr Moussa warned that Israel's pursuit of its settlement policies and practices raises extremely difficult questions about the real intentions of the present Israeli government.
- Egypt said it supported the decision to postpone the imposition of sanctions on Sudan for 30 days to give the Sudanese government more time to consider its position.
- Mrs Suzanne Mubarak opened the Cairo International Children's Book Fair.
- Prime Minister Kamal Ganzouri announced that the government's bill on the tax on agricultural land is meant to make life easier for owners and tenants by not imposing any new taxes on farm produce.

- Supply and Trade Minister Ahmed Gueily announced that the council of ministers will discuss setting up a cotton compensation fund and that this would have a capital of 700 million pounds ($206 million). He said the export target for this year was 1.5 million qantars (75,000 tonnes).
- An official security source denied Sudanese reports that Egyptian police detained and tortured a group of Sudanese students.
- Ganzouri said the parliamentary bill on a free zone in the Gulf of Suez will be ready within a few days for submission to parliament and approval by the end of December.
AL-AKHBAR
- Amr Moussa on settlement policy.

- Oil Minister Hamdi el-Banbi announced a new petrol discovery in the Belayim area in the Gulf of Suez, in an area operated by Petrobel, a joint venture between Agip SpA and the state's Egyptian General Petroleum Corporation.
- Ganzouri said the government would do what it could to help the victims of floods in the south.
- Police arrested an Israeli driver who tried to buy goods with a counterfeit $100 bill.
AL-GOMHURIA
- The land tax will stay the same for the next five years.
- Amin Bassioui, formerly the head of the Egyptian Radio and Television Union, has been appointed chairman of the newly created Egyptian Satellite Company (Nilesat)
AL-WAFD
- The government has ignored the victims of floods in the provinces of Aswan and Qena. The Ministry of Public Works expects more floods in the south.
-- Cairo newsroom +20 2 578 3290/1
